title: Disadvantage
excerpt: When you have disadvantage on a d20 roll, you roll two d20s and use the lower result. Advantage and disadvantage cancel each other out.
markdown:
# Disadvantage

Sometimes a special ability or spell tells you that you have disadvantage on a d20 roll. When that happens, you roll a second d20 when you make the roll. Use the lower of the two rolls.

## Rules

- If multiple situations affect a roll and each one imposes disadvantage, you still roll only **one** additional d20
- If you have both [[advantage]] and disadvantage, you roll only one d20-they cancel each other out, even if you have multiple sources of advantage or disadvantage

## Common Sources

### Attack Rolls
- Attacking a target you can't see imposes disadvantage on the attack roll
- Attacking from hiding while heavily obscured gives attackers disadvantage to see you
- Attacking a prone target from more than 5 feet away gives you disadvantage
- Attacking while prone gives you disadvantage on the attack roll
- Making a ranged attack when a hostile creature is within 5 feet of you gives you disadvantage

### Ability Checks
- Using a skill you're not proficient in while under certain conditions
- Some spells impose disadvantage (like *Bane*)
- Environmental factors (dim light gives disadvantage on Perception checks relying on sight)

### Saving Throws
- Being poisoned gives you disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks
- Being frightened gives you disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while the source of fear is in sight
- Being restrained gives you disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws
